repository.corpname: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

did.abstract: The Lillian Press papers (dated 1953-2018, undated; 5.22 cubic feet; 14 boxes) comprise correspondence, reports, publications, photographs, meeting minutes, subject files, notes, newspaper clippings, planning journals, speeches and essays, and assorted administrative records related to Press' advocacy for mental health, education, and education reform in Kentucky through careers with the Kentucky Department of Mental Health, Appalachian Regional Commission, Governor's Scholars Program, National Conference of Governor's Schools, and Kentucky Oral History Commission.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by subject into 9 series. Where possible original folder names were retained.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Lillian Lil Henken Press was born October 18, 1924, in Everett, Massachusetts. She received a Bachelor's degree magna cum laude from Boston University in 1946 and a Master's degree from the then-new Boston U. College of Communications. She and her husband, O. Leonard Press, entered graduate school together in 1947 two weeks after their marriage. While in Boston, Lillian worked as a reporter and writer for a daily newspaper; editor and press representative for American Red Cross; account executive for a public relations agency; and assistant to the press secretary of Massachusetts Governor Maurice Tobin.

In 1952, Lillian and her husband Leonard moved to Lexington, Kentucky, where she joined the staff of the newly arrived radio station WVLK. She remained there until 1960, rising from copywriter to program director. Several years after the birth of their only child, Lowell, in 1961, Lillian became a volunteer for the newly formed Central Kentucky Mental Health Association. In 1964, at the request of the Association, she directed a survey of mental health resources and needs in nine Central Kentucky counties, as part of a nationwide initiative by President Kennedy. The recommendations offered and publicized in the final report of that survey were significant factors in the later development of Kentucky's statewide mental health system of community mental health centers. To implement the recommendations, Lillian then organized and developed Kentucky's first Regional Mental Health Board which, under her direction, launched Kentucky's first two Comprehensive Care Centers with help from Kentucky's Department of Mental Health, led by Commissioner Dr. Dale Farabee. This became the prototype for a state system of community mental health centers that Dr. Farabee spread across the Commonwealth. In 1967, Lillian was appointed Executive Assistant to Commissioner Farabee. In 1975, she left this role to move into a Senior Associate position with Farabee and Associates, a consultancy firm started by Dr. Farabee after his retirement from the Department of Mental Health. During this time, Lillian started the Sunbelt Institute for Training and Education, first as a division of the firm, then later as an independent for-profit company.

In 1980, Lillian moved to Virginia to accept a position as Special Assistant to Al Smith, Federal Co-Chairman of the Appalachian Region Commission appointed by President Jimmy Carter. In late 1982, she was recruited by Governor John Y. Brown to organize and direct Kentucky's Governor's Scholars Program the following year. Lillian returned to Lexington and served as GSP executive director from 1983 to 1992, and the program became a model for other such schools. In 1987, Lillian organized 28 other state Governor's Schools into the National Conference of Governor's Schools (NCoGS) and served as its chair/president until 1992. NCoGS has since established a Distinguished Achievement Award in her name.

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Lillian chaired the Kentucky Oral History Commission. During her retirement, she turned her attention to increasing participation of citizens, particularly women, in the political process. In late 2002, she organized The Women's Network, Advocates for Democratic Principles.

Lillian received an honorary degree from Centre College in 1992 and was a member of the Centre College Board of Trustees for 26 years. In 2006, she received the Martha Layne Collins Leadership Award from Women Leading Kentucky. In 2008, The Women's Network elected her the first recipient of the Lillian Press Distinguished Leadership Award. In 2015, she received an honorary doctorate of humanities from the University of Kentucky.
Lillian Press died on April 26, 2020, and is buried at Lexington Cemetery with her husband, Len.
Milward Funeral Directors. Lillian Henken Press, obituary. Accessed September 15, 2022. https://milwardfuneral.com/obituaries/687-lillian-lucille-henken-press

Kentucky Historical Society. Description from Kentucky Oral History Commission Collection, 2010OH07, Lillian Press Oral History Project. Accessed September 15, 2022. https://www.kyhistory.com/digital/collection/Ohist/id/3373

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2022ms018: [identification of item], Lillian Press papers, 1953-2018, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries, Special Collections Research Center.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: 2021ms036, O. Leonard Press papers, 1953-2018, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries, Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lillian Press papers (dated 1953-2018, undated; 5.22 cubic feet; 14 boxes) comprise correspondence, reports, publications, photographs, meeting minutes, subject files, notes, newspaper clippings, planning journals, speeches and essays, and assorted administrative materials related to Press' advocacy for mental health, education, and education reform in Kentucky through careers with the Kentucky Department of Mental Health, Appalachian Regional Commission, Governor's Scholars Program, National Conference of Governor's Schools, and Kentucky Oral History Commission. The collection series are organized chronologically. Subseries are arranged by subject according to Press' original labeling and organization where possible.

The Kentucky Department of Mental Health series includes assorted publications, public relations materials, reports, financial statements, surveys, conference materials, correspondence, grant and budget materials, speeches, and newspaper clippings related to mental health organizations and activities in Kentucky. The series includes materials from the Kentucky Department of Mental Health, the Kentucky Mental Health Association, the Kentucky Mental Health Foundation, and the Public Corporation of Mental Health, including photographs of hospital conditions and Department of Mental Health events and fundraisers. Materials related to hospice and long-term care are also included.

The Appalachian Regional Commission series includes publications, correspondence, project materials, reports, publicity materials and newspaper clippings, and assorted administrative records on the ARC.

The Governor's Scholars Program series includes budget, grant, and funding records, Board of Directors materials, correspondence, assorted administrative records, lists, planning journals, publicity materials and publications, student and alumni materials, and assorted materials related to Kentucky education.

The National Conference of Governor's Schools series includes assorted administrative files related to the Board of Directors, early planning and incorporation, conferences, correspondence, events, the history of NCoG, lists, and newsletters.

The Kentucky Education Reform Act series includes materials related to education and reform in Kentucky, including clippings, publications, essays, press releases, correspondence, surveys, school board minutes and volunteer programs, legislation and legislators, and strategic planning. The series also includes administrative records, reports, and publications from the Prichard Committee for Academic Excellence and the Partnership for Kentucky School Reform.

The Kentucky Oral History Commission series includes agendas, budget and grant materials, meeting minutes, reports, and publications from Press' time as Chair of the Commission. Assorted documents from the Kentucky Historical Society and Kentucky History Center are included, as well as materials related to a civil rights oral history project.

The Personal series includes correspondence, event invitations and programs, memorabilia, and materials related to Press' political interests and involvement. Of particular interest is the extensive correspondence between Press and William T. Young.
The Media series contains two tapes, duplicates of the same content, labeled Robert Hillenmeyer – Mental Health.

The Photographs series includes images from throughout Press' career. The Kentucky Department of Mental Health subseries contains images primarily from awards banquets and social gatherings. Images of doctors, patients, and hospital conditions are also included. The Appalachian Regional Commission subseries contains images primarily from Al Smith's retirement dinner from his position as Co-Chairman. The Governor's Scholars Program subseries contains images of GSP staff and events. The Governor's Office subseries contains group photos of Governor Martha Layne Collins' staff, as well as images from fundraising events, dinners, and award presentations. The Assorted subseries contains images of unidentified groups, individuals, and events.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Libraries, Special Collections Research Center.

did.materialspec: Note from Lowell Press: "Warning! One of these pictures is very disturbing, These pictures show some of the conditions that the Mental Health professionals of the 60s and 70s were fighting to change and improve. From the 'ESH' on the back of one of them, I believe these might be from Eastern State Hospital. - Lowell"
